div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: THE MOTOR-OMNIBUS PANIC
div.p: No one who is a follower of the letters and diaries of the early Victorian era can fail to be struck, says the "Daily Mail," by the close resemblance between the outcry there was at that period against railways, and the storm of abuse that is now breaking upon the motor omnibus. The feeling of dislike and distrust of everything that is new is ineradicable, not only in homan nature but in everything which hath life : "Omne ignotum pro horrifico " It is true of animals, and the mass of mankind has not yet got over the animal instincts of bieng afraid of the unfamiliar.

In the early years of railways the most gloomy prophecies were made as to the penicious effects they would have on the human race. They would destroy life_jopd limb whole salp, and all who esoaped matilation would by their poisonous fumes. The .country would be utterly ririned by the twin plagues of smoke and dust. The earth would cease to yield its increase and passenger wo nil be stricken with'heart-disease brought on by the excessive speel at which traios travelled 4at that time it was about twenty- five miles an hoar. Many highly respeotabls and even eminent men declared their belief that railways, were the invention of the devil, introduced io brdet to lure to their deetractioo all who were foolhardy enough to use (hem.

Fortunately, little heed was paid to the prophets o? evil. RulwayT went ahead. England supplied them to the world and sent her engineers to teach their ose to other nations. We look back nowadays and laugh at the faint hearts and slow coaches who. seerionsly proposed to prohibit the steam-engine. Oar descendants will have the laugh of this genera, tion for being so terribly afraid of the motor- omnibus. Tjjiat this usefal vehicle, already a god send to thousands of Londoners, is capable of great improvement, no one but a shareholder woold deny. It it only too true that it makes a great deal of noise, that it causes a smell which many people find exceedingly up- pleasant, and that the steering often leaves much to be desired. But no invention ever issued from the brain of mao in petfeof form.

There is, too, a vast deal of exaggeration in the complaints that are made by unhappy correspondents to newspapers or across the dinner table, where nowadays the plague of motor omnibuses is a fruitful topic, the most violent in- their deounpiations often being motor maniacs themselvbs. Professor Sir James Dewar is a great authority qn air, liquid, and atmospheric, and when he tells us gravely that motor omnibuses fill our luogs with minute partioles of salphor and oarbonfc oxide, which are poisonous, wary people Should tremble. But the qaestion which we feel inolined to pat to Sir james is, how much of these poi- sjns will hurt a man ? We are oonsoious of no toxio symptoms at present We have to take so many risks, aooordiog to science, in oar daily life they it scarcely seems worth while to fall into a panic over one more.

At the same time, we are in fall agreement with Sir Edward Henry, the Commissioner of Police, who thinks the moment has oome to oall upon the motor-omnibus companies to fulfil their pledges of improvement Sir Edward fioa wisely he'.d his hand so far from fear of damaging a young, important, and promising iaduetry. He hes given it a good term of probation; be now means to call upon it to justify his wiie and patient attitude. We most have less noise; drivers must steer less emtioally ; they mast not oarry away eo many*lamp posts; and they must lubricate so as to-avoid giving off clouds of evil-smelling vapour. This is not a counsel of perfection, it .is merely a qaeation of mechanics and reasonable precau-tions. If the present dim panics cannot overcame these ills, othera-wijl soon he in the field with impfoved vehicles and more skilful drivers.

div.head: PAN-ISLAMISM.
div.p: The Sultan aptepts a very grave risk by posing as ,champion of combatant Islym. He mast be aware (says the 'Globe") that it is for easier to light a conflagration ot that character than to extinguish the fierce flames. If he hoped by stirring up Mohamedan fanaticism in Egypt to gain Frftnoh support, he mast now reoog- uise that he made a profound blunder. Oar neighbours, like oareelves (he rulers of great Mohamedan populations,^ already perceive that the same danger that menaoes England in Northern Africa threatens their military oontrol in the sooth western portion of earth extensive territories. It is"atwo-edged sword which Abdal Hamid is so recklessly nourishing ; be may succeed in oansiug some troahle, bat it will be at the heavy cost of lopping off Anglo-Freuoh friendship,-the ohief mainstay of Turkish territorial integrity. There are great military Powers not very remote from the Golden Horn to whom that prospect is, naturally, fulh of attractiveness, and they must have been .oovertly mirthfal when Mr. Haldane announced the coming redaction of oar Mediterranean* garrison, despite Lord Cromer's argent demand for the immediate reinforoement of the British contingent on the Nile. But that insanity has not orossed the ChauneL On the contrary, the ' Tempe" loudly oalls for the dispatch of additional troops to the places chiefly effected by the Saltan's misohidMns intrigues Great Britain is, however, far more deeply ooo- oercei io fighting militant Pan Islamism tooth and nail. Not to speak of othfcr parts of her Empire, she rales over fifty millions of Mos lems in Iadia, and although the large majority are loyal, the Wahatyes still exist. The oom- igpoest prudenoe Would dictate some aag- mentation of the home Reserve for strengthening the Indian command in any emergency,/ instead of attentuating it, as Mr Haldane proposes.

'Pbe report of the Eastern Telegraph Go. for the aft months ended March 31 stutes that the revenue amounted to £628,319, ordinary expenses td £191,468, expenditure relating to maintenance of cables to £46,464, leaving a balance of £390,387, exclusive of £39,471 brooght forward. After providing for prior charges, etc., there remains a balance of £342,267, out ot which the directors plaoe £10,000reserve for maintenance of ships and £150,000 to the general reserve fund. They recommend a final dividend on the Ordinary stock for the year of 1| per cant, and a bonus of 2 par cent, making 7 per cant, for the year, leaving £2,767 to bo carried forward. It hx; been deoided, in conjunction with the Western Telegraph Company, to lay an additional cable between Porthchrnow and St Vincent (Cape de Verde).
Panto at a Theatre

Considerable alarm was caused on Tuesday night at the Ambassadears Theatre, at Ghezi- reb, Cairo, owing to the explosion of the gw emmating from the petroleum motor which jdrives the dynamo for the supply of electric lbdit Fortunately, no serious harm was done, though .one artiste was ^lightly soirched about the face and another's leg was bruised. The explosion naturally caused great excite ment, and the artistes rashod out into the garden, the ladies giving vent to nervous shrieks, while the greater part of the audience ran toward the entranc?. Everybody, however, was soon reasiured that nothing 'serious hid happened and retnrned to their places, bit it - WAS found tint the damage cou'd nos bo repaired that night, and the entrance mo cy was refunded to the ticket-holders.

MORE QUESTIONS IN. PARLIAMENT.

In the Honse of Commons last Thursday, Mr. Macveagh asked, the Foreign Secretary whether Lord Crnner and the British Judicial Adviser to the Egyptian Government were at present in Europe upon a three months' leave, and whether, in view of the prevailing unrest in Egypt, they wore proposing to return to their respective posts.

Sir E. Grey Both Lord Ciomer and Sir M. Mcllwraith are now/in this conntry on the n final leave of absence. If tho sit nation in Egypt became such as to rfqnire their presence, they would no doubt return.

div.head: THE SERSINA. AFFAIR.
div.p: Mr. Macveagh asked the Foreign Secretary whether, at the time when the late Captain Boll was fifund by the patrol of the army of occupation at Sereina, water was being banded to him by oae of the native villagers ; whether that villager was. thereupon killed by the patrol; and whether ary proc3edings were taken against those who killed the villager, and with whit result.

Sir E. Grey : 1 have no confirmation of the statement made in the question. The informa-tion obtained by the military inquiry has sho^n that no change against British soldiers can 4b 0 sustained in the evidence forthcoming in oonRecptfn with the dead body of a native found in this neighbourhood; The investigation is being contkined by the parquet.

div.head: AFTER DENISHWAI.
div.p: To THE EDITOR' OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.''

Sir,—Yesterday I receivod an amusing reve-lation of the view taken by the villagers of Denishwai themselves respecting the retribu-tion recently inflicted on their village. I met fellah of Denishwai and irqnired of him what he thought of the punishment that had come upon them. I expected to hear, of course, a pitiable tale of the harrowing tcenes enacted in the village on the memorable Thursday. What was my surprise, however, to find that, these had made no impression upon the man's mind, but thit all that he thought about was his pocket. Io antwer to my question, he replied in an aggrieved tone "Algum etlakhbat wal ataba zadet ("The threshing floors have been aiixed up and the watchmen's tax increased.") I told him that these were small matters, and attempted to draw his interest back to the more striking events of the fateful^ Thursday, asking him what he thought of the seve/o punishment then inflio/ed on his fellow- villag^fK. With the utmost nonchalance he, however, exclaimed "Gat hum dahya el gum' etlakhbat wal alaba zadet" ('Let them go to the devil, for are they not the cause of our thre-hing Boors being^mixea up and our watch
men's tax being increased").

As showing how far British sentiment is removed from native feeling in such matters, it is curious to contrast the oompassionate interest taken by the British Parliament in the severity of the sentences inflicted on the vil-lagers with the view thus taken by the people of the locality themselves.—Yours, etc,
A MAN ON THE SPOT.
July 24th, 1906-:
N.B.~" Ataba" is the threshold .of a door, and the watchmen's tax in the villages being levied at so muoh per threshold is freque .tly termed the "ataba."

div.head: LORD CROMER ANd tHE HOME GOVERNMENT
div.p: Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman evidently imagines that by observing silence in con-nection with Lord Cromer's recently expressed desire for additional British troops io Egypt, that embarrassing request will slip from public memory. Up to date, this policy of reticence has been submissively observed even by the loquacious War Saoretary. In yesterday's debate on Mr. F. E Smith's motion, it was not alluded to, directly or indirectly. The assumption is, therefore, that Ministers are agreed to flout the great statesman who has regenerated egypt and to ignore the dangers conseq ent on the rapid spread of Pan-Islamism of whfoh he has given solemn Warning. And why is that insult? to ,be offered and that grave risk to be ran? Miinly, if not solely, to enable Mr. Haldane to carry through his wonderful scheme of streugthen- ing-the Army by largely -reducing its fighting strength. If Ljrd Cromer's urgent^ demand were acceded to, it would bo impracticable to get rid of the 20,0 0 trained troops Mr. Haldane has marked out for elimination. The Government still entrenches itself be hind the "mandate" which it supposes it received from the electorate at the beginning of the year. Bat that ridiculous pretext for endangering the, 'safety of the Empire is knocked to bit^ in the case of the Egyptian garrison by tin fact that when the General Ejection took place, Lord Cromer had not sounded any note of alarm. It was the im-pudent invasion of Egyptian territory by a Tirkish fores. dispatched for the purpose, followed by the Deniihwai outrage aud thj discovery of'Ottoman plotting at Cairo, that brooght the hidden danger to light. Even the most rabid militarists will Bcaroaly charge Lord Cromer with any -addiction to the use of the sword, whilq, as we h-ive shown, the "mandate" foolishness does not hold water as an excuse.. (' G'obe")

div.head: SHIPPING STATISTICS.
div.p: EGYPT'S MARITIME COMMERCE.
The new Statistical Department of the Ministry of Finance has began well, and has just issued a most interesting return of navi-gation at the Egyptian .ports and on the Suez Canal.

In the tr8t'quaiter of 1906, 877 vessels, displacing 2,032,379 tons gross, entered Egyptian ports and landed some 30,000 pas-sengers, while nearly 24,000 passengers embark- ed on 885 vessels displacing 2,044,003 tons which cleared. Alexandria, with a total maritime movement of 1,039 vessels, of ooarse heads the retarn.

Classified by nationality, the vessels flying the British fltg are most numerous, 408 having pat in aqd 401 havifig pot ont of Egyptian ports? the arrivals and departures Jjptp, Austria, France. and Germany. come next, with Greeoe, Italy, russia,' and Turkey following? in the order given, Io the figures for the "Other Powers" we note a deoided and promising increase of,Roumanian shipping.

Separate retarns for thn pilgrim traffic, the number of Warships entering and leaving the Canal, and the unmber of sailing vessels enter-ing or leaving the Egyptian ports, with the Suez Canal retarns, which we have already d if cussed in reviewing the Canal Company's report for 1905, make this report of great interest and value.

There are omissions, .it is true. Figures relating to passengers landed at the ported of Egypt are given as accurately as possible, being deduced from information supplied by the Board of Quarantine oonoerning vessels bound for Egyptian ports as well as those whioh, transiting the Suez Canal, /landed passengers at Suez and Port Said without performing operations of oommeroe, and being therefore excluded from the movement.of shipping in these ports respectively. As regards passengers embarked on vessels clearing from the ports of Egypt, neither the Forts and Lights Administration nor the Board of Quarantine are able to obtain any information on the above matter, and the Department has therefore been compelled to have recourse to various shipping agencies and consulates for information regarding passengers leaving the port® of Egypt; asking them at the same time to supply the neoesssry data oonoerning goods embarked and landed, in order to obtain some idea of the maritime oommerce in the Egyptian ports.

"It is to be muoh regretted," writes M. Randone," that some agencies, fortunately very few, have not acceded to the request of this office for information and it is consequently incomplete. The data concerning passengers embarked have been published, lor they approximate closely to the truth. As regards the movement of goods, information beipg very deficient, it is impossib'e to give data of any valoe. I would express the hope that those shipping ageooies which have not so far sup. plied this Department with the desired information, may appreciate the importance of the inquiries undertaken io this publication and in the future supply, with increasing accuracy, the data neoesiary for their completion. I feel it my duty to accord my best thanks to the Consols and shipping agent), whose asaistanoe will be di^y acknowledged in the fourth quarterly return of the current year, for the information they have been good enough to plaoe at the disposal of this Department, and also desire to thank them in anticipation of similar support in the futare."

div.head: ACROSS THE SREAT SAHARA.
div.p: BRITIsH RESIDENT'S ADVENTUROUS JOURNEY.

The British Assistant Resident at' Kario has started on an adventurous journey, which has for its object the crossing of the great Arab caravan route through the Tripolitan hinterland to Kano. Fhe projeot has given rise to some oomment abroad, and has even led to the saggestioo that a German traveller is endeavouring to oross the Great Sahara in oannexion with the Pan-blamio movement

The traveller in question,is named Visoher, and this apparently has led to the belief that he is a derman. Mr. Hans Visoher, Assistant Resident at Kano, is an offioial of Sir Frederick Lagard's Administration, and is, of course, a British subject. He is of Swiss extraction. So me months ago he returned to Ragland on leave, and in Febraary lost went/to Tripoli, intending to return to his poit atjKano by tbe^fosert route through the hinterland of Tripoli.

Mr. vischers original idea was to start fromTripoli in February last, in order that he might reach Kano at the end of April* While he was in Tripoli mskingpreparations and obtaining the necessary permission from the Turkish authorities to travel in the "forbidden hinter land," a number of pilgrims, returning from Mecca to the distriotff round Kano, hearing of the presenoe of a Northern Nigeria official, asked for facilities to return to their homes by the desert route, aud it was then .agreed that Mr. Visoher should go with them in his offioial capacity. Delay ensued in reference to certain objections which were raised, and in securing the necessary permits wh'ch wore obtained through the British Embassy in Constantinople. The Turkish Government raised mo difficulties whatever, and on july 9th Mr. Visoher, acoompanied by the pilgrims, left Tripoli, travelling to Kano, via murzuk, the chief town of fezzan, six hundred miles across the desert from Tripoli. his journey has no political significance.

div.head: MENDICITY IN ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: ACTION OF POLICE.

An order has been is ued by the gouvernor putting the followiug streets out of bounds" to merchants: —rue des Pyramided Rue Babel Akhdar, Rue Champolliou, in the Menshieh quarter; and the salah el DIN, Gate da cairo, Emir Abd el Monneim, Metaalli, eglise Debbane; Mahmoud Pasha Falaki.^and attarin streets in the Attarin quarter.

The rae Eglise.Uebbane is usually infested by indigent Greek families. the mothers sit on other people's door steps and Watch for viotims. Should some one who ris likely to pay to be let alone appear in the distance they let slip their offspring, who trot behind and in front of him, clutch at bis hand or clothes, and make him so nervous of treading on them that he usually pays and flies.
Au intelligent little Greek girl is said to have obtained 10 P.T. at a aiogle haul by catching the hand .of a passing Englishman and vooiterating "Papa" at the fall pitch of a strong pair .of lungs.

Of the mendicants of theMenshieh we cannot speak with experience. Tbe.rue de la Gare da Caire was haunted till lately by an Italian who professed to be a cripple, and the neighbour* hood of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi's bar was till recently—if it is not now—the beat of two mariners, apparently American or English, one of whom wore a patoh oveFVdii- oolonred eye and both of whom had one formula : ' Drop us a piastre, guv'nor, and 'elp a pore man from starvin'. "

div.head: CAIRO LAND AND FINANCIAL CO.
div.p: The above is the title of a new Egyptian company which has just been formed With a capital of L.E. 80,000, divided into 90,000 shares of L.E. 4 each, which have been en-tirely subeoribed by the promoters in the following proportions: Ahmed Khairy 4Bey, 2,500 ; Mr. Alphonse Colnoei, 2,500 ; Ornate Max Lavison, 7,000; M. Edward Oattaoni, 2,000; M. Maurice Mosseii, 9,000 ; Mr. Albert Cattaoai, 2,000 ; Mr. George Merz bach, 2.000.

The principal objects of the company, as stated in the decree of authorisation, are the purchase of urban and inral lands, their re-sale for oash or deferred payments, either in blook or in lots, and all banking opera-tions connected therewith. The offices of the company will be in Cairo, and the first board will he composed of Messrs. Adolphe Cattaoai, Ahmed 'Bey Khairy, Comte M. Lavison, Gustave Cattaoai, Eli Mosseri, L. Carton de Wiart, and A. Coladci.

div.p: H.H. Prince Mohamed Aly arrived at Inter, laken from Paris on Monday week, and will remain there for the greater part of the season.
H.H. Prince Ibrahim Pasha, Hikfay arrived at Marseilles yesterday week.
At the last moment, Mr. machell has post-
poned his departure for england for a few
days.
The salary of Mr. Dunlop adviser to the Ministry of Pablio Instruction, will be increased to L.E 2,000 per annum at the beginning of next year.
Mustapha Pasha Kamel was stopping at the Carlton Hotel, London, last week.

We are pleased to learn that Crookshank Pasha's son, Master Hany Crooks hank (aged 13) took the 5th scholarship last week at Eton College, among 70 competitors selected from the preparatoryschools of england. He hails from Sommer Fields School, , Oxford, where judge Dilberoglu has two sons and
Hogg one boy.

Mohamed Bey Khalil moudir of Ghizeh, has been granted 15 days' leave from date.

Ismail Pasha sirri Inspector of the projects Circle in the Ministry of public Works, has been granted three months' leave, to date from the 15th August next, and Hassan Bey Wassef, Inspector of "Irrigation in the Fayoum, will be acting Inspector of the rrejects Circle in the Pasha's absence.

div.head: THE LATE LADY SuRZON.
div.p: UNIVERSAL EXPRESSIONS OF SYMPATHY.
Lord Cnrzon has received many messages of condolence on the lamented death of Lady Cuizoh. \

The King sent a sympathetic message, Queen Alexandra despatched her secretary to convey an expression of her deep sympathy with his lordship, and a cablegram of condolence has been received from tho . Viceroy of India.

The Prince of Wales wired frjmc uiiajkct, and the Princess of Wales sertt eqne\y from Marlborough House. The Pre sident of the United States and the United States-Ambassador in London have also forwarded messages of condolence, and throughout the whole day following her decease telegrams and messages arrived in a constant stream from all parts of the oonntry.

During the day tho Prime Mini iter oalled, and t^e Pope offered his sympathy through the mediarn of Mgr. Tylee, Domestio Prelate to his Holiness. The Earl of Cromer called and inscribed on his card "Deepest* sympathy;" while Lord Milner wrote upon this 'With most sincere sympathy." The Speajct\ offered the "sincere sympathy and sorrow" Af Mrs. Lowther and himself.
Lord Carzin, who is greatly affeoted by his wife's death, is keeping to his room, and his brother, Mr. Frank Curzon, is aoting for him.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: T/ie Money Market,

As we foreshadowed last 6e, tie money market shows continued base, and the Bank return, shewing a reserve ' of £26,874,437, making 49 17 of the liabilities, fairly represents the improvement in the sitnatioD. Tile Paris oheque ra'e is down to 25.14}. ard.money is very plentifal in that market. There is nothing to indicate any ooming stringency, and as far as the market can see, nothing hot the move- of the Amerioan crops* is likely to oreate any special demand, and this, as we have before indicated, the Secretary of the United States Treasury is taking steps to satisfy with
the enormous stock at his ooinmand.

The pessimistic and even panicky feeling in the stock markets is likely to oaose further disinclination to invest in any securities, and the £18,060,000 required for the last Russian loan on the 1st of August will be drawn from so many centres that it will not be likely to create a scarcity. Of oonrse the state of affairs in Russia is intensely unsatisfactory, and it is difficult to forecast the result of possible events, which we most admit might upset all oalonla- tionk. At presentthe market has a foil supply, and 1} to 2% is all that can he obtained by lenders for short loans. The discount houses are, however, very conservative in their rates, which to-day are 3} to 3}% for three months' hankers bills.

With reference to the issue of £1,500,000 Treasury Bills, in part replacement of the bills doe on Jnly^th. the ''Times" in its financial article says that "besideanthe £',000/ 00 pnVlioly issued, there are /also some hills outstanding held by the Debt Commissioners. The phrase "in part replacement" is thus justified, but.the mystification that it oaosed is a orther evidence of the desirability of more looid statements concerning the management of the national finances.
Tho Stook Market*.

The average Londoner is but poorly oonsti- toted to effectively resist the depressing effect of semi tropical weather, hence the high temperature this week prodnoed a general feeling of lassitude. This being the oaae, the stook markets became an easy victim to adverse influences and ramonrs, which are never far removed iroin the neighbourhood of Tfirog- morton Street. Russia has again been a disturbing element. The feeling of confidence which had followed the reports that a Parlia- mentaiy Ministry 'would sneoeed the present administration disappeared when it was realised that there was little probability of the I'sar making such a democratic oonoession, and the official recognition of the troubles in that country observed in the postponement of the visit of the British fleet to Cronstadt increased the bearish tone. The latest news from Rassia is even more unsatisfactory, and there is an -uDeaayJeeling that the real situation is more serious^ than the telegrams of correspondents make out. We are told that yesterday intense pessimism prevailed on the Petersburg Bxohange, while the ^lamp in Russian securities here has undoubtedly hesn responsible is DO small degree for the general weakness of stocks. It is suggested that Russian bonds are being deliberately hammered with the object of forcing the hand of the Antooraoy, but it is too much to expect that at the present jauctnre shrewd financiers are likely to add to their already numerous anxieties the rdle of coercionist when the Tsar and bis relatives are concerned. The fall in the bonds most be wholly ahoribed to extreme nervousness regarding the situation in Rassia. This morning's advices from St. Petersburg have had a demoralising effect in the markets, and the bonds have shown a farther considerable deolire. The "panicky" feeling has also seriously influenced the gilt edged and other sections.
Consols.
Foreign Bonds

After firming op to 77j on Monday, Rassian Fonrsare now about as low as they have ever been. The bearish influence is working havoc in this seotioD, and the liquidation shows no signs at present of ceasing, inasmuch as Faris is taking the lead in this respeo/ The FOOTS olose to night at 74} and the new loan at 7 discount, as compared with 76 } and 4} disooant last week/ Japanese stocks show little ohange.
Horne Ralls,

The dividend announcements* of the home railways have commenced. The Brighton line maintains its rate of 3}%, and the Great Eastern is increased by } to 1 The Tilbnry dividend, on the other hand, is lower at 3|%, and the Metropolitan rate at 1}% is less by 1%. City and Scnth London is increased by } to 2}%. Notwithstanding the generally satisfactory nature of these returns the market failed to benefit by them, and Great Eastern sha'O', in fact, olosed } down after the dividend was announced. Movements generally have been in a downward direotioD, this being attributed to the depression* ruling in other markets.
Americana,

There has been certain anfco.int of irrega- larity in the movements'rf American railway shares, but on the whole prioes have kept firm at higher levels. New York Central and Unions have been the leading features, -the former dosing abont 4 points higher on the > week, and the latter about 3} better. Chicago- Milwaukee have again been fairly well supported and show an appreciable rise on our last quotations.
Egyptians

Prioes keep firm in the Egyptian marked, though there is still no baseness to report, hat this is not surprising considering the state of markets all-roond. National Bank of Egypt are distinctly better at *25g buyers, also Agri onltaral Banks, which are wanted at 9}}. There is also an eDqniry for the last issoe of Agrfoqltnral Bank 3}/' Guaranteed Debentures at aboai lg disooant. Daira Sanieh are 16}-17 and the Deferred are nominally 96 98. Egyptian^ Estates Afe again in demand, and olose 11 buyers, the Deferred being 10-11. Daira Sagar remain the same at *5, and Delta Preference at 11$. Delta Land and Investment have advanced slightly to 3} bid, and Egypt has bought Land and General ap to par and a fraction over. Corporation of Western Egypt are } premium, after being a doll market at

Laud Bank at 8g, and Union Fonoifere at 6 are quite unchanged. Egyptian Markets are nominally 1} and 8alt and Sola 1^. Bank of Roamania have ohanged hands at 10. Khedi- vial Mail Ordinary are bid for at 32s., sellers have withdrawn.
Mining,

Sooth Afrjcaj^ mining shares generally are doll, with prices about last week's low level. The lamented death of Mr. Beit has had bat little influence on the market, as it is antici* pated that there will not be any liquidation of his estates which oan affect the market Rand Mines leave off at 52 and Etst Rands at 3|.

The movements in Egyptian mining shares have been fractional, bosioeu being at a low •bb. Nile Valleys and Egyptian Mines have each lost sixpence /at 5s. Od. and Is. 6d. rospeotive'y, and United Afrioan Ex Joration are t't lower at {}.

div.head: Telephone Company of Egypt, Limited.
div.p: CAIRO-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONE.--Rates as follows P.T. 5 for each 3 minutes, or fraction of 3 minutes; P.T. 10 for over 3 up to 8 minutes communication.
